Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I named him after the Greek writer. You know Homer, of course?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I made his name "Wells" because I could tell he was very deep.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: "Good night, you Princes of Maine, you Kings of New England!"

Speaker: adopting mother
Dialogue: There's something wrong with him! He never makes a sound.

Speaker: adopting father
Dialogue: Do you think we could have a look at someone a little different?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Don't be frightened. Everyone is nice here.

Speaker: pregnant woman
Dialogue: Do you live here?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I just belong here.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Homer, if you're going to stay at St. Cloud's, I expect you to be of use.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Dr. Larch! Dr. Larch!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: We've got two new patients, one to deliver.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: First pregnancy?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Yes, for both.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I presume you'd prefer handling the delivery.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: All I said was, I don't want to perform abortions. I have no argument with *you* performing them.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: You know *how* to help these women-- how can you not feel *obligated* to help them when they can't get help anywhere else?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: One: it's illegal. Two: I didn't ask how to do it--you just showed me.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: What *else* could I have showed you, Homer? The only thing I can teach you is what I know! In every life, you've got to be of use.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Have you ever had ether, Dorothy?

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Once, when they took out my appendix.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: No one's touched your appendix.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Whatever it was... the ether made me sick.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: It won't make you sick this time, Dorothy--not the way I do it, just a drop at a time.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: I can't pay for this, you know--I got no money.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: One day, Dorothy, if you have any money, a donation to the orphanage would be very much appreciated.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Only if you can afford it.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Try to think of nothing, Dorothy.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: That was good, Carla--that was *perfect*. Everything's fine.

Speaker: carla
Dialogue: I don't wanna see it!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: You don't have to see it, dear. Don't worry.

Speaker: carla
Dialogue: I don't even wanna know what sex it is--don't tell me!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: We won't tell you, Carla. You're going to be okay.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Your *baby's* going to be okay, too.

Speaker: carla
Dialogue: I don't wanna know!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: He's a big boy!

Speaker: carla
Dialogue: Let me see him, for Christ's sake--I wanna see him.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Would you mind having a look at Dorothy?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: There was no visible wound?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: No. The fetus was dead. Her uterus was virtually *disintegrating*--my stitches pulled right through the tissue!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It looks like scurvy.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Scurvy! Ah yes, the curse of the old- time sailor, suffering long periods at sea with no fresh fruits or vegetables. Homer, Dorothy isn't a *sailor*!

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: She's a prostitute, isn't she?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Did you look in her purse?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I looked everywhere else!

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: It's called French Lunar Solution.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: It's not ergot, it's not pituitary extract, it's not oil of rue...

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: It claims to restore monthly regularity.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It's obviously an aborticide.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Obviously.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Christ, it's oil of tansy!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I don't know it.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: If you take enough of it, your intestines lose their ability to absorb Vitamin C.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: In other words, scurvy.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Good boy. Good job. And you call yourself "not a doctor"!  Keep an eye on her--she's in trouble.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Take care of that, will you?

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: I'll help you.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: He *sniffs* that ether! I've seen him do it!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It's because he's too tired to sleep. He has to.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: He *smells* like he could put you to sleep!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: He's a doctor, Buster--doctors smell like ether.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: *You're* a doctor, Homer--you don't smell like ether.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I'm *not* a doctor. I haven't been to medical school--I haven't even been to high school!

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: But you've studied with the old man for *years*!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I'm *not* a doctor!

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Homer.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Fuzzy is not uncommon. I tell you, there's something about the premature babies of alcoholic mothers. They seem susceptible to every damn thing that comes along.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I haven't read that.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I haven't, either. But you *will*. The morons who write the books should do a little research *here*.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: But isn't Fuzzy just... well, underdeveloped?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: When *doesn't* he have bronchitis? I wouldn't call his bronchial infections "underdeveloped." Would you?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: What is it, Mary Agnes?

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: Look!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Did you bite it?

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: I don't remember.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It looks like you bit it--it'll be all right.

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: Maybe I was kissing someone and he bit me.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: No, you did it yourself. Maybe in your sleep.

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: I must have been *dreaming* of kissing someone.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Story time, Fuzzy!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: "Oh Lord, support us all the day long..."

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: "Then in Thy mercy grant us save lodging, and holy rest, and peace at the last."

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: "A dog, which had lain concealed till now, ran backwards and forwards on the parapet with a dismal howl, and collecting himself for a spring, jumped for the dead man's shoulders."

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: "Missing his aim, he fell into a ditch, turning completely over as he went; and striking his head against a stone, dashed his brains out.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Good night, you Princes of Maine! You Kings of New England!

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: Why does Dr. Larch *do* tht every night?

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: Maybe to scare us...

Speaker: copperfield
Dialogue: No, you jerk.

Speaker: steerforth
Dialogue: Dr. Larch *loves* us!

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: But why does he do *that*?

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: He does it because we like it.

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: Buster is mine. You two get Copperfield and Curly. Nobody touches Fuzzy.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Stop it! No fighting! *Share* the snowballs!

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: They're *our* snowballs! They *stole* them!

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: They attacked us--just like the Japs!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Listen to you, Fuzzy! You've been running. You get to the shower!

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: I know the type--they'll take one of the babies.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Wilbur, the adopting couple is waiting in your office.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Life is waiting.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Where's the name sheet?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Nobody's named this one yet.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: It's my turn!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Henceforth you shall be... Little Dorrit!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: He doesn't like it.  He's a boy, That's why.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Can't a boy be a Dorrit?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I don't think so.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: You do it then.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Henceforth you shall be... Little Wilbur.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I'm not crazy about the "Little..."

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Okay, he's just a Wilbur then.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: We haven't had a Wilbur here in a year or so, have we? We used to have *dozens*!

Speaker: copperfield
Dialogue: They picked Hazel! The idiots chose Hazel!

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: If people want to adopt one of us, they should have to take the oldest first.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Please, Mary Agnes! This is Hazel's special day--don't make her feel sad.

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: Hazel's practically the youngest of us. She should be the *last* to leave!

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: At least Hazel can talk. Usually they take one of the stupid babies.

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: They take the babies so they won't ever have to tell them that they were orphans!

Speaker: hazel
Dialogue: I'm not a baby!

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: If you cry, Hazel, they'll just send you back.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Mary Agnes, that's not true!

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: That's what they did to me!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: You *wanted* to come back--that's why you cried.  You can cry if you feel like it, Hazel. You cry as much as you want.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: It is strictly for our orphans' sake that I destroy any record of their natural mothers. Of course they will, one day, want to know. But orphans, especially, should look forward to their *futures*. Not back to their pasts.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Hi, Curly. You going somewhere?

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: I thought they might take me.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: They wanted a girl.

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: Nobody ever wants me!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You're one of the best, Curly--we couldn't let just anyone take you.

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: Dr. Larch wouldn't let just anyone take *any* of us!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: That's true.

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: Nobody's asked for me, have they?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Nobody special enough, Curly.

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: You mean somebody asked?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Only the right people can have you, Curly.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Let us be happy for Hazel. Hazel has found a family. Good night, Hazel.

Speaker: the girls
Dialogue: Good night, Hazel! Good night, Hazel! Good night, Hazel!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I was dreaming about you. How beautiful you were!

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: You weren't dreaming about me.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I was!

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Then I wasn't beautiful.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: You were! You *are*! It was fantastic.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: It was just the ether, Wilbur...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Are you okay? Can I get you anything?

Speaker: distraught woman
Dialogue: No one but me ever put a hand on me, to feel that baby. Don't you want to touch it or put your ear down to it?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: distraught woman
Dialogue: Put your ear there. Go on.

Speaker: distraught woman
Dialogue: You shouldn't have a baby if there's no one who wants to put his face right there!

Speaker: distraught woman
Dialogue: Stay right there. Right where you are. Stay right here. Right here.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: Do you ever think about leaving this place to go find them?

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: I mean your parents.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I know who you mean. I think about leaving here, but not to find *them*.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Whoever they were, they didn't *do* any of the things parents are supposed to do. Dr. Larch did those things, and Nurse Edna, and Nurse Angela.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: Yeah. But sometimes I wish I could meet mine, anyway.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: What for, Buster? What would you do if you met them?

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: Uh... I'd like to show them that I can cook, a little.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You cook very well!

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: And that I can drive a truck!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Better than I can!

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: Sometimes I want to meet them so I can kill them. Just sometimes.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: Homer, you know I would never kill anyone--you know I wouldn't.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: I think Mary Agnes could kill someone.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I doubt it. She's just an...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: ...emotional girl.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: What's she so emotional about?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I don't know. She got left here, like the rest of us, didn't she?

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: He thinks she's his *mother*!

Speaker: copperfield
Dialogue: He doesn't think she's his mother, Fuzzy.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: He does so! He *loves* her!

Speaker: carla
Dialogue: How could she be his *mother*?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: They want to replace me! The Board of Trustees wants to *replace* me!

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: They just want you to hire some new help.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Some new *things* would be useful. I don't need any "new help."

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Homer! I need you!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I thought you took care of this. It always breaks in the same place. It's your splice, isn't it?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It's *your* splice! You blame me for everything!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Angela, we need a new movie, a new projector, a new typewriter--*that's* what they should replace around here!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: We have a delivery. Imminent, in my estimation...

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Homer, would you get this one?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: She's a patient, right? She should see a doctor.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Homer, you are a skilled and gifted surgeon. You have near-prefect obstetrical and gynecological procedure.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I just mean I'd rather fix the movie. Tonight.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Sure. Okay. You splice. I'll deliver.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: Homer... doesn't King Kong think the woman is his *mother*?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Uh, sure--that's what Kong thinks, all right.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: That's why Kong loves her!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I thought it was my turn.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: It is. I'll get this. You go ahead.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "Whether I shall turn out to be the hero of my own life, or whether that station will be held by anybody else, these pages must show."

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "I was a posthumous child. My father's eyes had closed upon the light of this world six months, when mine opened on it."

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: His father's dead, right?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: That's right, Fuzz.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: Is *your* father dead?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Cirrhosis--it's a disease of the liver.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: *Liver* killed him?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: *Alcohol* killed him--he drank himself to death.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: But did you know him?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Barely. It hardly mattered that I knew him.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: Did you know your mother better?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: She's dead now, too. She was a nanny.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: What's a nanny do?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: She looks after other people's children.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: Did you grow up around here?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: No. She was an immigrant.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: What's an immigrant?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Someone not from Maine.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: No one's going to hurt you, dear. Have you come to visit us? We have beds, you know. Have you had any breakfast? What's your name?

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Her temperature is a hundred and four.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: How old are you, dear? Thirteen?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Twelve? Are you twelve, dear?  Three months?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Are you *four* months pregnant?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: She's at least *five*.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Dear child, it won't hurt when I look. I'm just going to *look*.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Tell me: you haven't done something to yourself, have you?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Did you go to someone else?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Stuck *what* inside you?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Listen, you've been very brave. I'm going to put you to sleep--you won't feel it anymore. You've been brave enough.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: That's a heavy sedation.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: You *bet* it's a heavy sedation! The fetus is unexpelled, her uterus is punctured, she has acute peritonitis, and there's a foreign object. I think it's a crochet hook.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: If she'd come to you four months ago and asked you for a simple D and C, what would you have decided to do? *Nothing*? *This* is what doing nothing gets you, Homer. It means that someone else is going to do the job--some moron who doesn't know *how*!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I wish you'd come to *me*, dear child. You should have come to me, instead.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: What'd she die of?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: She died of *secrecy*, she died of *ignorance*...

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: If you expect people to be responsible for their children, you have to give them the right to decide whether or not to *have* children. Wouldn't you agree?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: How about expecting people to be responsible enough to control themselves to begin with?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: How about this child? You expect *her* to be responsible?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I didn't mean her. I'm talking about... adults.  You know who I mean!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: It's just a marvel to me that you still have such high expectations of people.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I'm happy I amuse you.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Try to look at it *this* way. Buster and I are sitting right here beside you. We could have ended up in the incinerator!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Happy to be alive, under any circumstances--is that your point?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Happy to be alive... I guess so.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: So many children. Are they all orphans?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Well, this *is* an orphanage.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Oh, they're getting into the car... watch your fingers!

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: I'm the best.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You are?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: The best? Wow! The best at *what*?

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: I'm the best one.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Here, blow...

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: I really *am* the best, I just have a cold.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Blow! There, I bet that feels better.

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Curly, come here!

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: *Tell* them! I'm the one.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I'm sorry. They're not used to seeing a car like this.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: It's okay--I don't mind.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: We brought some chocolates for the kids.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Chocolates. How *thoughtful*.

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: I'm the best! *Tell* them!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: You're the best, Curly.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: So, Mrs...

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Candy. Candy Kendall.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Wally. Wally Worthington.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: How many months are you?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Two.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: So, now, uh... you're not... I mean, do *you* do the--

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: No. Dr. Larch will be performing the procedure.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Ah, well... okay. Good! I just wondered...

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Excuse me, Homer. Dr. Larch said this one is your turn.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Oh, dear--I'm sorry. I meant the circumcision. That boy you delivered on Tuesday...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Sure. Fine. Have you prepped him?

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: I'll get started.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: I think it was the ether--the smell got to me.  God. This is all my fault.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Steerforth got into the pantry--he's eaten all the pie dough.

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: He wasn't sharing it, either.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: He's down the hall, throwing up.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: What kind of plane are you flying?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: A B-24 Liberator.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Liberator...

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Have you enlisted?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: They wouldn't take me. I'm Class IV-- I've got a heart defect.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Really! Is it serious?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: No, it's not serious. I'm just not supposed to get excited. You know-- no strain, no stress. I try to keep calm all the time.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Oh, well. I don't imagine there's any strain or stress around *here*!

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: How is she doing?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Just fine.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Boy or girl?

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: It was nothing--it's all over.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: It's all over, honey.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I would like to have a baby, one day. I really would.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Why, of course--you can have as many children as you want. I'm sure you'll have very beautiful children.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: You'll have Princes of Maine! You'll have Kings of New England!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I suggest you find yourself some fresh air, Lieutenant.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Uh... it's the end of October.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: Is that soon?

Speaker: steerforth
Dialogue: That's a few months away, Fuzz.  I still don't feel so good.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: Oh. It's the best time! How come we only get pumpkins once a year?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Don't get too excited, Fuzzy.

Speaker: fuzzy
Dialogue: Why can't we have pumpkins for Christmas, too? We don't get any good presents at Christmas, anyway.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Has anyone offered you anything to eat?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Actually, someone did. I just didn't think I could eat anything.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I wonder if you might give me a ride.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Sure! Be glad to! Uh... a ride where?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: We're heading back to Cape Kenneth.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Cape Kenneth...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: That sounds fine.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Doubtless you'll let me know what immensely worthwhile or at least *useful* thing it is that you find to do.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I wasn't intending to leave here in order to be entirely useless--I expect I'll find some ways to be of use.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: In other parts of the world, I suppose there are other ways.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Are you really so *stupid* that you imagine you're going to find a more gratifying life? What you're going to find is people like the poor people who get left here--only nobody takes care of them as well! And you won't be able to take care of them, either. There's no taking care of *anybody*-- not out there!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You know I'm grateful for everything you've done for me...

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I don't need your gratitude.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I don't need this--I know all about my condition.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: It's your heart--you ought to take it with you.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Going where? Does he have a plan of some kind?

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Will he be back soon?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I don't know! He's just leaving--  *That's* what he'll do--he'll see the world!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: He's leaving...

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: He'll need clothes... some money...

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Let him try to *make* some money! That's part of "seeing the world," isn't it?

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Oh, just stop it! You knew this was going to happen. He's a young man.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: He's still a boy--out in the world, he's still a boy.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Just find him some clothes, Wilbur. He could use some clothes.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I think these will fit you.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: You'll need some money--just a little something, until you find a job.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I'm okay--I can walk.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: I don't want you to walk--I want to carry you. Should I put the top up? It might get cold.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: No--keep it down. I want to feel the air.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Coming with us? It's always a good idea to have a doctor along for the ride.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I have to go, Curly. I'm sorry.  I couldn't find Buster. Will you tell him...

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Let us be happy for Homer Wells...

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Actually, the Army has given me leave twice. First when my father died, and now I'm on leave to help my mother-- I'm just trying to get her ready for the harvest. She's no farmer. Apples were my dad's business. And with the war on, she's short on pickers.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Wally thinks apples are boring.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: I never said they were boring.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You said, "Apples aren't exactly flying."

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Well, they aren't.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I think I'd probably like the apple business.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: You're a little overqualified, aren't you?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: No, I'm not. I need a job.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: The only jobs are picking jobs. Picking apples is truly boring.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: There! You said it was boring.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Well, *picking* them is! It's about as exciting as... walking!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Is your family in the apple business, too?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: No, but I work there--I like it. My dad's a lobsterman.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I've never seen a lobster.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I've never seen the ocean, either.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: You've never seen the *ocean*?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: That's not funny... that's *serious*.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I couldn't have a baby with someone who's leaving me--I didn't know what else to do!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: He's going to be dropping bombs on Mandalay! They're going to be shooting at him!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Where's Mandalay?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Burma!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Oh...

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I can't have a baby alone. I don't even know if he's coming back!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Honey, honey... of course I'll come back.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You don't *know*, Wally. You have no *idea*!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Stay away from me!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: This is all normal. Don't worry. The abortion procedure... it affects you. It's the ether, too. It'll take a little time.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: I don't *have* any time. There's a *war*!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It's all very normal.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: You ought to cut that shit out--it's terrible for you.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I'm a little worried about the...  ...about how much bleeding is okay.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It should taper off tomorrow, but it can come back again. You have cramps?  They'll ease up, almost entirely. As long as the bleeding isn't heavy, it's normal.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Give it here!

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: What was *that*?! Come over here!

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: It's called the Burma run. It's about a seven-hour round-trip flight between India and China.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "Burma run" because you fly over Burma...

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: *And* over the Himalayas. That's called flying over the hump.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: I've got thirty-five minutes to climb to fifteen thousand feet--that's the first mountain pass.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: What lousy luck--I mean your orders... to draw an assignment like that!

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Actually, I volunteered.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It's the flying, right? You love to fly, don't you?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: I love the bombing, too. But there's also the Himalayas--they have the most wicked air currents in the world. I wouldn't miss flying there for anything.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Uh, look... if you're serious about wanting a job, picking apples isn't that boring.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Oh, I would love that, Wally.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I guess I'll see you around the orchards. Thanks for everything.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Sure... I'll see you around.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I love you, Wally.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: I love you, too. See you tomorrow.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Come on. You have to meet my mom.  If it comes up, I've been at a wedding. That's where I met you, at the wedding.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: This is Homer Wells--he's the most overqualified apple picker you'll ever meet, but he's dying to learn the apple business.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: How do you do, Homer Wells...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: How do you do...

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Were you a friend of the bride or the groom?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Homer is everybody's friend, Mom... the bride's, the groom's, mine, Candy's, *everybody's*.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Well, perhaps you'll come to dinner, Homer...

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Not tonight, Mom--he's got to meet *Mr. Rose*!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You already used up the hot water!

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: You're usin' my soap, ain't you?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I ain't usin' no soap--it's too cold to bother with soap!

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: There ain't never enough hot water, soap or no soap.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: They're migrants.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Migrants?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Yes. They pick fruit, all kinds. They travel up and down the coast with the seasons.  The trick to Mr. Rose is, you have to let him be the boss.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: That sink's backed up again, Wally. I thought you was gonna get me a plumber.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Rose, this is Homer--Homer, this is Mr. Rose's daughter, Rose.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Rose Rose?

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: Pretty, ain't it? You a plumber?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: No, no--Homer is a new *picker*. He's going to stay here with you.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: He's stayin' *here*?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Homer's got no experience, Arthur, but he's smarter then I am. He's a fast learner.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: See you later.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: So. What should I do now?

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: What kind of a name is Homer?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It's the name of a cat. Originally. Well, not *originally*.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It's just my heart.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: What you got a picture of your heart for?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: There's a little something wrong with it. Just this part here--the right ventricle. It's slightly enlarged.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: So what?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Yes, so what. It's nothing serious, really. Just a small defect.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: They told Muddy his feet was too flat!

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: And you was "generally unfit," as I recall.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Do you like to read?

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: I can't read. Nobody taught me.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: What does it say there?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "I looked at the stars, and considered how awful it would be for a man to turn his face to them as he froze to death, and see no help or pity in all the glittering multitude."

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: More?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Since you're the one who's smart enough to read... what's this?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It's a list of rules, it seems.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: *Whose* rules?

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: They're for us, I suppose.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Go on and read 'em, Homer.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "One. Please don't smoke in bed."

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: It's too late for that one!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Okay...

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Remember this! In the morning, when the tall grass is wet, you can make the Jeep slide on the grass. Can you feel it?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: It's almost like flying.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: What about the trees?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: The trees are flak--antiaircraft fire from those geeks on the ground.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: I was just showing Homer the orchards... kind of a geography lesson.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I know what you've been doing.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You've been giving him a *flying* lesson!

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Didn't you?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Yeah, it was great.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: He thinks people *like* to get whacked by branches.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: *Homer* liked it!  Didn't you?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Yeah, sure. There's no stress or strain around here...

Speaker: vernon
Dialogue: What's wrong with you?

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: You getting along okay?

Speaker: big dot
Dialogue: Where is that Candy?

Speaker: florence
Dialogue: Did she leave you, Wally?

Speaker: debra
Dialogue: Who's the boy?

Speaker: florence
Dialogue: Wally, you can marry Debra if Candy leaves you!

Speaker: big dot
Dialogue: Wally's gonna marry *me* if Candy leaves him!

Speaker: debra
Dialogue: You can marry all three of us, Wally!

Speaker: florence
Dialogue: We can take turns.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: You girls make it hard for a guy to go off to war.  But I'll leave my best man here to pinch-hit for me.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: Uh... I'm shipping out sooner than I thought. I just wanted to be sure you were settled in--and happy enough, considering...  Are you bored stiff? Or can you stick it out for a bit?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Uh... actually, picking apples is as much excitement as I want for a while. I'm grateful for the job.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: You're the one who's helping *me*, Homer. You're going to give my mom a little peace of mind while I'm gone. Candy, too.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Well, sure... that's good, then.  All I mean is, I'm lucky I met you.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: I don't think so, Homer. *I'm* the lucky one.

Speaker: wally
Dialogue: You want to fight about it?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I guess so...

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Wilbur, you should read this.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: It's from the Board. Another letter.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: I think they're just testing some ideas for our next meeting.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Dr. Holtz seems nice. I think he only wants to help...

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: He is a goddamn psychiatrist--of *course* he wants to "help"! He'd be happy if he could help *commit* me!

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: It's that Mrs. Goodhall you have to be careful of, Wilbur.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: One has to be more than "careful" of Mrs. Goodhall--she has sufficient Christian zeal to start her own country! I'd like to give her a little ether.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: So what are you going to do?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: "Homer Wells, born Portland, Maine,

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Homer was born *here*, in, what was it, 1922?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: "...graduated Bowdoin College, 1935,

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: This is *your* life story, Wilbur! You just changed the dates!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: "An internship and two years of training at the Boston Lying-in, South End Branch. For his age, he was judged an accomplished gynecological obstetrical surgeon; he is also experienced in pediatric care..."

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: You *invented* him! You've completely made his up!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Don't you understand? The board is going to *replace* me! That's what the "new blood" is *for*!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: You mean they'll replace you with someone who won't perform abortions.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Well, we can only guess about that, Edna. They *are* against the law.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: These *credentials* are against the law!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: We all know who trained Homer--his credentials are as good as mine are. Don't you be holy to me about the *law*! What has the law done for any of us here?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: So here is my candidate. What do you think?

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: But what about school records? Homer doesn't have any *diplomas*...

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: He *will* have them, Edna.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Oh, Wilbur, I don't know...  We don't even know where he is!

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: What view?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Are we supposed to be up here? The rules said...

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: *What* view?

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: I bet the view looks better from the Worthin'tons'.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: Daddy, I'd like to be in that Wally's shoes *every* night.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: What's lucky about that?

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Thank you, Arthur.  And how is our Homer working out?

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: No rotten apples?

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Rose... dear girl, I'm sure I can find you some other clothes.  You must have some things that would fit her.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I have a *ton* of things that would fit you.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Arthur, there's no such thing as a young woman who's got all the clothes she needs.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: So. Not bored yet?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I'm *never* bored! It's all very... different for me... here.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Uh... have you been *feeling* okay?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: When I'm not thinking about Wally. I'm not good at being alone.  ...I don't suppose you've seen a lobster yet.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You have to come to my dad's lobster pound and see one, then.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Okay...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I better go.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I don't think Mr. Rose would leave without you.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Sorry!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Come next week!

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: Whoa--look at that Homer! He's gettin' all dressed up for supper tonight!

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: He ain't gettin' dressed to have supper with *us*, Peaches!

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: Yeah, we can wait all night for the water to come back on--you just go on and take your time.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Hungry?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: They're the garbage-eaters of the ocean's floor. The seagulls clean up the shore. The lobsters clean up the bottom of the sea.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: They eat everything?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Everything that falls to the bottom.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: It's time somebody ate *them*.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: They made him a captain already-- *Captain* Worthington!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Daddy, it's a letter to *me*.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: He mentions Homer, too, you know.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Wally said to say, "Hello."

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Oh! That's... nice.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Wally said the most spectacular hits were in the oil fields at Yenangyat.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: A movie *outside*?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Yes. But it's closed all the time now, because of the blackout.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: People watched the movies in their cars?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: When they watched at all. Do you like movies?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Yes! I've only seen one, though.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You've seen only one movie? Which one?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "King Kong". It's really good.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I haven't seen "King Kong" since I was a kid!

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: That's a pie apple, Wilbur. Homer said you're not supposed to eat it!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: So he's an apple expert, is he?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Oh my, yes! This is a *far* superior taste--and crisp, too! You know, so many apples are disappointingly mealy. I wonder of most of the apples in my life weren't meant for pies!

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Wilbur, he picked them for us himself...

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: You don't find it depressing that Homer Wells is picking apples?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Or that he can't be bothered to write us a proper letter? A dissertation on apples, we don't need!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: He probably doesn't make much money picking apples--he must have had to pay to send them, too.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I wouldn't worry, Edna, that he doesn't have money. If he gets hungry, he can pick his dinner!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Wilbur, it's a *gift*! How can you be angry with Homer for sending us a *gift*?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I'll show him a *gift*! I'll give him a gift he can *use*!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: But you looked as if you liked it.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I *did* like it. All I said was, "It's not 'King Kong'."

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: First she loved him, then she didn't, then no one else could have him...

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: She *did* love him!  How many women have you known?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: And what did she die of, exactly?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: She was torn apart! She died of a broken heart.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Oh, sure!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: What's the *medical* explanation?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Well, she was in a weakened condition...  I don't know! What about "King Kong"?! Is that medically possible?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: At least King Kong knew what he *wanted*.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: What is you *doin'* with that Candy, Homer?

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: He's makin' history, I suppose.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: You ain't gettin' in no trouble, I hope.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: No trouble.

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: That Candy--she's the nicest girl I know!

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: She's about the most beautiful girl I ever seen--I don't know if she's the nicest.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: She's the nicest *and* the most beautiful girl I've ever known.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: That sounds like you is in trouble already, Homer.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I'm not in trouble.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: Yeah, you is. I know when people is in trouble, and you is.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: ...and his *pathetic* resume is the best I've seen. Though I find it hard to believe the Board would be interested in this character.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: He looks like a bleeding-heart missionary *moron* to me, but that's going to be the problem with any doctor interested in coming here!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: *No*! I don't want to know him! He's doing *missionary* work--in *India*! I wrote him *weeks* ago, but he's either too holy or too busy to answer. Maybe he got killed in the war!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Does it *snow* in Bombay? One winter here and we'll be shipping him south, in a *coffin*!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Then I suppose we can look forward to catching various diseases from him!

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I'm not talking about his medical qualifications. It's the *Christian* thing that bothers me--I just don't see it being of much *use* around here.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Anyway, I was just showing you this guy as an example of what's available-- I didn't think you'd be interested.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I suppose it wouldn't hurt to *meet* him. What's his name again?

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Dr. Homer Wells.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I just hope he won't expect us to say *Grace* all the time.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: *Very*!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: I just wanted to ask you...

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Edna! Come dance with me! Let's be foolish tonight.

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Does he *know* he's supposed to be in India? Does he even *want* to come back?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: He's a field hand! What could possibly hold him there?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: What about the worms? Most of these apples are the drops--off the ground, right? There have to be worms.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Them people drinkin' that cider, they don't know there's a cigarette in there!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: You mean *swimmin'*. I ain't goin' in that vat to fish out no cigarette!

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: Just say you're in the *apple* business, man. That's the only business you wanna be in. Just say it.

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: You don't wanna go in the knife business with Mistuh Rose--just say you're in the *apple* business, Jack!

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What business are *you* in?

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: You're lucky he didn't cut your *nipples* off, man.

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: The good news, Jack, is you're half- undressed for *swimmin'*...

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: Yeah, that cigarette ain't hard to find when you're properly undressed.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Give men that. I know how to do it.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: Oh, I suppose you is a doctor, Homer?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Almost.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: We should drown that damn Jack in the vat!

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: Yeah, you really showed him, Daddy-- you just about cut your own hand off, and all you cut off *him* was his clothes!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You're a natural. You were born to drive a car like this.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You think? Maybe I was.  I love this place!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: The screen is enormous! Imagine King Kong up *there*! Have you seen a lot of movies here?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Yes... and no. When you come here, you don't really care about the movie.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You don't care about the movie?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: What are you so crazy about the movies for?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It was my favorite night at the orphanage--movie night. We'd race into the dining hall. Of course everyone wanted to sit in front, so we'd be packed in so tight you could feel the kid next to you breathing.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: At least you were never lonely.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I didn't say that. Growing up in an orphanage, you're always lonely. You're just never alone.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You're not alone in the bathroom, or... or in the shower... you're never alone in wanting the last piece of meatloaaf, or even in your own bed on a cold morning.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You don't miss it?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I miss things. I miss... people.  I miss reading to the boys.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: But you had so much *responsibility*.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I never *asked* for any responsibility.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Just a little privacy.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Privacy is exactly the point of drive- in movies.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Did you come here with Wally--to *not* watch movies?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Sometimes... movies mostly bore Wally.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Ah-ha.  So what is that--a radio?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: The *speaker*. For the movie sound.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Scrunch down like this.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: How could you not *care* about the movie?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You just cuddle. You come to hug... to kiss. You don't *come* here to watch the movie.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: That's what *I'd* come here for. I'd watch the movie.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Not with the right girl you wouldn't.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: Fuzzy? Fuzzy?

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: What are you going to tell the little ones?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I'll tell them Fuzzy was adopted.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: Why would the little ones believe that *anyone* would adopt him?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: They'll believe it because they want to believe it.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: Shouldn't we tell Homer?

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: If Homer wanted to know what was happening here, he could pick up a telephone and call us.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: It was a family with a better breathing machine then the one Dr. Larch built.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Some mail for you, Homer.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: And some clothes for you, dear--  let's go see if they fit.

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: Ain't you gonna see what it is, Homer?

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: Sorry, Homer...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Aren't you worried that people will cut their feet?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Nobody will swim here until next summer. By then, the water will have rubbed the glass smooth against the sand--there won't be any sharp edges.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: See? That's last year's glass, or from some year before. I put glass here every year. The ocean makes it beautiful.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Give me your hand.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: *Nobody* volunteers for the Burma run--he said so himself. And nobody knows *me* better than him! So how am I supposed to feel? He's a bomber pilot and I'm just selfish, I know. Well, I'm *not* a brave little girl and I'm *not* sorry.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I *know* this was right.  I told him, too.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I *know* this was right.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: This is easy--I'm not hurrying.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: He's in a big hurry, all right. I told you he's in trouble.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Just tell me. Do you want me to go? Do you want me to stay?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: It will be okay.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: *What* will be okay?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: We have to wait and see. I think that, for *everything* in life, you have to wait and see.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I'll just move on, get another job somewhere.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Every time you throw a snail off the dock, you're makin' someone start his whole life over.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Maybe we're doing the snails a favor, Daddy.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: It's gettin' late. I think I'll pack it in.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Good night, Daddy.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: We'll just have to wait and see.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: I used to hate it when Wally went back to college--even when it was just college! And this was when his father was still alive... I hated it even then. Naturally I hate this more.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: What I mean is... I would like it very much if you thought you could be happy here, Homer.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Mrs. Worthington, I feel I'm very lucky to be here.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: There's not a lot of work in the winter, and you'll have to tolerate Vernon--even Wally despises him, and Wally likes everyone.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I think Wally will be fine, Mrs. Worthington--he seems indestructible to me.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Just promise me one thing.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Uh... sure.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Just promise me that, if there's a blizzard, you'll move into Wally's room until it's over.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Good-bye. Have a safe trip home. Thank you, again, for all your hard work.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Good-bye, Arthur.  Homer, I'll see you tomorrow?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: We all set, I think.

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: We see you next harvest.

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: Don't freeze to death, Homer.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Go on and freeze to death if you want to, Homer.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: You just stay out of trouble, Homer!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Olive told me.  You might have told me yourself.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I'm just waiting and seeing. Like you said.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I've looked at so many women... I mean, I've seen *everything* about them, *everything*... but I never felt a thing. I felt nothing. Now... with you... it *hurts*... to look at you.

Speaker: larch
Dialogue: I think we may have lot him to the world. He's not coming back.

Speaker: hero
Dialogue: Who's that?

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: It's that Homer!

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: It's that Candy, too...

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: It look nicer then home!

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: How is that Wally doing?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Oh, he's fine! I just heard from him. He's bombing all these places...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: ...bridges, oil refineries, fuel depots...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Where's Jack?

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: He just wasn't up for the trip.

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: They ain't drops--I picked 'em off the tree!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Do you think I'm having a good time? Do you think I'm just *teasing* you? Do you think I *know* whether I want you or Wally?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: So we should "wait and see." For how long?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I grew up with Wally. I began my adult life with him.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Fine. That's all there is to it then.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: No! That's not all there is to it! I love you, too--I *know* I do.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Okay, okay--I know you do, too.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: It's a good thing I didn't have that baby, isn't it?

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: She used to eat with us. Now we ain't good enough for her, I guess.

Speaker: hero
Dialogue: She ain't hungry, maybe.

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: She ain't hungry every mornin' 'cause she's sick every mornin'.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You okay, Rose?

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: I guess you must like watchin' me be sick...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I don't like watching anyone be sick.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: How many months are you?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You're not yet three months, are you?

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: Not yet. What do you know about it?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I know more than I want to know about it. Who's the father?

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: Don't trouble yourself about it, Homer--this ain't your business.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: But you don't look very happy.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: *Happy*! What are you thinkin'? How am I supposed to take care of a baby! I can't have a baby.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Rose, please listen. Whatever you want to do, I can help you.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: What I mean is, if you don't want to... keep the baby, I know a place where you can go.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: You think Daddy's gonna let me go anywhere? I ain't going *nowhere*.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: Why don't you just go back to your pickin', Homer? I can take care of it myself!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Rose, listen--don't *do* anything. You know, I mean to yourself. Please listen...

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: We should take her to St. Cloud's. That much is obvious, isn't it? Let her make up her mind when she gets there...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I told her! She doesn't feel she can do that. Something about her father not letting her go anywhere...

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Well, we have to help her!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: We have to do *something*. Don't we?  Homer?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Hi...

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: Hi...

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I've got some more clothes for you-- I just keep forgetting to bring them with me.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: I don't need no more clothes, thank you.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I've been through this.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: You ain't been through what I been through, Candy.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Yes, I *have*!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Who's the father, Rose?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You want to have the baby?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I know where you can go. Homer and I can take you...

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: I can't go nowhere.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Is it the father? Does he know?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You can trust me. Is it Jack? It's not Jack, is it? It's *Muddy*! Is it Muddy?

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: No. It ain't Muddy. Muddy's just...

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: It sure ain't Jack.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: She won't go to St. Cloud's!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Well, we can't force her. It's her decision.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You don't understand! It's her father...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Mr. Rose *knows*?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: He's the *father*! He's her baby's father!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Wait... *wait*! Are you sure?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: We've got to keep her away from that bastard!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Is it true?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Are you sleeping with your own daughter?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You're actually having sex with your own little girl? Is that possible?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You're lying. How can you... with your own daughter!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Go on, cut my clothes. I've got other clothes.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: But she's your *daughter*...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: She's *pregnant*. Do you know *that*?

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: Don't mess in this, Homer, if you know what's good for you.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: How long's this been going on, Muddy?

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: Long enough. You ain't gonna stop it.

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: There's my knife, Homer. It ain't gonna do *me* no good. You give that knife to Rose Rose, you hear?

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: You best just watch you ass, Homer! You don't wanna end up like Jack!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: No! No!

Speaker: major winslow
Dialogue: When the plane was hit, the crew chief and the radioman jumped close together. The copilot jumped third. All on Captain Worthington's orders-- the captain was still flying the plane. None of the men of the ground could see the sky--that's how thick the jungle was. They never saw the plane crash--they never *heard* it crash. They never saw Captain Worthington's parachute, either.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Why was he missing for twenty days?

Speaker: major winslow
Dialogue: Because the crew thought he'd gone down with the plane. They were hospitalized for almost a week in China before they were flown back to India. It wasn't until that they sorted through their gear...

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Who cares about their *gear*?

Speaker: major winslow
Dialogue: Three men jumped from the plane, but they had four compasses with them. One of the crew jumped with Captain Worthington's compass.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: He was in Burma for twenty days without a compass?

Speaker: major winslow
Dialogue: He followed the Irrawaddy River, all the way to Rangoon. Somehow he managed to avoid the Japs, but not the mosquitoes.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: Then it's malaria?

Speaker: major winslow
Dialogue: It's encephalitis B. He's recovering at Mount Lavinia Hospital, Ceylon.  Waist down. He won't walk.

Speaker: major winslow
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: There are no autonomic effects, are there?

Speaker: major winslow
Dialogue: No autonomic effects... that's correct.

Speaker: olive
Dialogue: When will he be home, Major?

Speaker: major winslow
Dialogue: Four weeks or so, right around Halloween.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: There are no autonomic effects, just the paralysis of the lower extremities.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Wally can have kids, a normal sex life...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: How about him not needin' the friggin' compass! How about that?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Daddy, *please*...

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Good night, kids. Don't catch cold-- it's gettin' cold already.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Good night, Daddy.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Good night, Ray.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Just tell me. I'll do whatever you want to do.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Isn't that like waiting and seeing?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: No. Nothing is nothing. I want Wally to come home. I'm afraid to see him, too.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I know.  Is *that* nothing.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: No, don't--that's something. Nothing is nothing.  Don't even look at me. I want...

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: ...to do nothing.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It's a tempting idea, I know... to do nothing.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Please don't move, don't go anywhere.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: *Go* anywhere? Of course not! That would be *doing* something, wouldn't it? We wouldn't want to *do* something. Let's just sit here all night!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: If you're trying to be funny, Homer...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I'm not trying to be anything--I'm just doing nothing! If I wait and see long enough, then--with any luck-- I won't *ever* have to make up my mind! Decisions can be painful, after all...

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Stop it! Just cut it out!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You got up! You *did* something! If you keep this up, you might be in danger of making a *decision*!

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: For God's sake, Homer, Wally's been shot down!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I know, I'm sorry.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: He's *paralyzed*!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: So do I.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: What do you want me to *do*?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Nothing. You're not the one who has to do anything.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: I ain't your business no more, Daddy. Please let me go.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Hey, hey! Stop it. Maybe I can help.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: That's right, Homer. This ain't your business.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Please listen to me! *Both* of you...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Mr. Rose, I'm in the *doctor* business.  If you want, I can help you. You don't have to go anywhere.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: One cervical stabilizer, two sets of dilators--Douglas points. One medium- sized curette, one small; one medium speculum, one large; two vulsellum forceps.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Merthiolate, ether, vulval pads, gauze--lots of gauze.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: No *almost* about it--I'm a doctor.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Get out of here, please.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Okay. Then you can be of use.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You better get some air.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: The bleeding should taper off tomorrow, but it can come back again. The cramps will ease up, almost entirely. The bleeding is usually much lighter in two days. As long as the bleeding isn't heavy, it's normal.

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: It's that Vernon--he keeps askin' where you and Homer and Rose Rose is at.

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: I told him that you all is sick.

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: Look at that. Them same damn rules is tacked up again!

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: Why don't you put them damn rules in the wood stove, Peaches?

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: I want to hear what they are, first.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: Homer, let me hear what they are.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "One: Please don't smoke in bed."

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: We heard that one already, Homer.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "Two: Please don't go up to the roof to eat your lunch."

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: That's the best place to eat lunch!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "Three: Please--even if you are very hot--do not go up to the roof to sleep."

Speaker: hero
Dialogue: What do they think? They must think we're crazy!

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: They think we're dumb niggers so we need dumb rules--that's what they think.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: This is the last one.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "Four: There should be no going up on the roof at night."

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: Why don't they just say, "Stay off the roof!"?

Speaker: hero
Dialogue: Yeah, they don't want us up there *at all*!

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: That's *it*?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: That's it.

Speaker: rose rose
Dialogue: It means nothin' at all! And all this time I been *wonderin'* about it!

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: They're *outrageous*, them rules!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Please don't make me say it again.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: No, that's not it--I just want to be sure I understand you.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I *helped* you not to think about Wally. You were so upset--you couldn't stand worrying about him, about his being killed and not coming back-- but when you were with me, you could stop worrying... well, for a while, anyway. This is how I helped you, right?

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Please... that's enough. I *loved* you, too--you know I did.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "...did." Well, okay.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Please don't...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: And now that Wally's coming back, and because he'll certainly *need* you...

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: You say that as though it's some awful thing!  I never stopped loving Wally!

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: At least there's no more waiting and seeing. At least I got to see the ocean.

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: Rose Rose has runned away!

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: She took off in the night!

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: She took off on the bicycle, man.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Where'd she get you?

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: *You* taught her, I suppose...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: There's more than one laceration, more than one cut.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Right?

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: That what happen--you lost you only daughter so's you killed yourself! That's what we say, all right.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: Do you think she'll be all right?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: She knows how to take care of herself.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: This came for you a couple of days ago. Olive asked me to bring it. With everything happening, I guess she forgot.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Sure. Thanks.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: I know you don't think much of being needed, or of me for that matter...

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: I'm sorry for what I said about Wally needing you. It was... unnecessary.

Speaker: candy
Dialogue: No, I'm the one who should be sorry. You have every right to be angry.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: No. You warned me. I didn't listen, but you warned me.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You told me you weren't any good at being alone.  You told Wally, too. Right?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: He's going to be fine, Wally's going to be fine. I know he is.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: Dr. Larch? Dr. Larch?

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: You ever see a palm tree, Homer?

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: He ain't never been outta Maine!

Speaker: hero
Dialogue: Ain't you sick of pine trees, Homer?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Thanks, guys... I'd like to go with you. But I've got to move on.

Speaker: muddy
Dialogue: Yeah, well... you could move on with *us*, man! You could move on somewhere *warm*!

Speaker: peaches
Dialogue: Homer, stayin' in Maine ain't movin' on!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: "Then, in Thy mercy grant us a safe lodging, and a holy rest, and peace at the last."

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: You know what? I did.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: It's from the ocean. It's for you.

Speaker: buster
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: mary agnes
Dialogue: We made up a room for you.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Wouldn't you be more comfortable by yourself?

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Homer, do you know what this is?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Sure. It's my heart.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: Actually, it's Fuzzy's. There's nothing wrong with your heart.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Fuzzy's?!

Speaker: edna
Dialogue: Dr. Larch wanted to keep you out of the war, Homer--that's why he did it. That's why he told you it was yours.

Speaker: angela
Dialogue: I think he worried about his own heart. He said it would never stand up to Homer Wells going off to war.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: "Thus I began my new life, in a new name, and with everything new about me... I felt... like one in a dream... The remembrance of that life is fraught with so much... want of hope... Whether it lasted for a year, or more, or less, I do not know. I only know that it was, and ceased to be; and... there I leave it."

Speaker: curly
Dialogue: What happens next?

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: That's tomorrow, Curly. Let's mot give the story away.

Speaker: homer
Dialogue: Good night, you Princes of Maine! You Kings of New England!
